749    /**
750     * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
751     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
752     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
753     */
754    public static float alpha(final float encoded)
755    {
756        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 25) / 127f;
757    }
758
759
760    /**
761     * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given HSLuv color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
762     * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
763     * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
764     * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
765     * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
766     * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
767     * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
768     * 0 chroma, and the most colorful value (a shade of purple) should have ??? chroma.
769     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
770     * @return a float between 0.0f and ??? that represents how colorful the given value is
771     */
772    public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
773        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
774        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
775        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
776        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
777
778        // HSLuv to Lch
779        if (L > 0.99999f) {
780            return 0f;
781        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
782            return 0f;
783        } else
784            return chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
785    }
786    /**
787     * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (exact) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
788     * combination, using HSLuv's versions of lightness and hue (not raw HSL). This is useful to know the bounds of
789     * {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater than 1.0f . Note that this version of chromaLimit() is
790     * a little slower than Oklab's version, because this has to go to greater lengths to become accurate.
791     * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
792     * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
793     * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 1.0f
794     */
795    public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness) {
796        final float h = hue - floor(hue);
797        float sin = TrigTools.sinTurns(h);
798        float cos = TrigTools.cosTurns(h);
799        float sub1 = (lightness + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
800        sub1 *= sub1 * sub1;
801        float sub2 = sub1 > epsilon ? sub1 : lightness / kappa;
802        float min = Float.MAX_VALUE;
803        for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
804            float m1 = m[i][0] * sub2, m2 = m[i][1] * sub2, m3 = m[i][2] * sub2;
805            for (int t = 0; t < 2; t++) {
806                m2 -= t;
807                float top1 = 2845.17f * m1 - 948.39f * m3;
808                float top2 = (8384.22f * m3 + 7698.60f * m2 + 7317.18f * m1) * lightness;
809                float bottom = (6322.60f * m3 - 1264.52f * m2);
810                float length = intersectLength(sin, cos, top1 / bottom, top2 / bottom);
811                if (length >= 0) min = Math.min(min, length);
812            }
813        }
814        return min;
815    }
816
817    private static float intersectLength (float sin, float cos, float line1, float line2) {
818        return line2 / (sin - line1 * cos);
819    }
820
821    /**
822     * Gets the color with the same L as the HSLuv color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
823     * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
824     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
825     * @param packed a packed float color in HSLuv format; does not need to be in-gamut
826     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
827     * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
828     */
829    public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
830        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) | 0x0000FF00);
831    }
832    /**
833     * Gets the color with the given H, L, and alpha, but ignores the given S and instead uses the furthest S
834     * from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
835     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
836     * @param H hue component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
837     * @param S saturation; ignored, and will always be maximized
838     * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
839     * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
840     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the H and L of packed
841     */
842    public static float maximizeSaturation(float H, float S, float L, float alpha) {
843        return clamp(H, 1f, L, alpha);
844    }
845
846    /**
847     * Gets the hue of the given HSLuv float color, but as HSLuv understands hue rather than how HSL does.
848     * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
849     * and 1 (exclusive).
850     * <br>
851     * This is the same as {@link #channelH(float)}.
852     *
853     * @param packed a packed HSLuv float color
854     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the HSLuv color space
855     */
856    public static float hsluvHue(final float packed) {
857        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
858    }
859
860    /**
861     * Gets the saturation of the given HSLuv float color, but as HSLuv understands saturation rather than how HSL
862     * does. Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue
863     * and lightness, and is between 0 and 1. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive).
864     * <br>
865     * This is the same as {@link #channelS(float)}.
866     *
867     * @param packed a packed HSLuv float color
868     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the HSLuv color space
869     */
870    public static float hsluvSaturation(final float packed) {
871        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
872    }
873    /**
874     * Gets the lightness of the given HSLuv float color, but as HSLuv understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
875     * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
876     * and 1 (inclusive).
877     * <br>
878     * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
879     *
880     * @param packed a packed HSLuv float color
881     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the HSLuv color space
882     */
883    public static float hsluvLightness(final float packed){
884        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
885    }
886
887    /**
888     * A different way to specify a HSLuv color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
889     * color but calculating them directly in the HSLuv color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
890     * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma.
891     * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
892     * like {@code lightness} and the method {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the
893     * lightness should be equivalent to {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same
894     * chroma and lightness, but different hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or
895     * both chroma values exceeded the gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If
896     * a chroma value given is greater than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use
897     * {@link #hsluvHue(float)}, {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #hsluvLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and
898     * lightness values from an existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
899     * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
900     * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
901     * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
902     * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
903     * @return a packed HSLuv float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
904     */
905    public static float hsluvByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
906        hue -= floor(hue);
907        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
908        if(lightness <= 0f) return hsluv(hue, 0f, 0f, alpha);
909        if(lightness >= 1f) return hsluv(hue, 0f, 1f, alpha);
910        return hsluv(hue, Math.max(chroma, 0f) / (chromaLimit(hue, lightness) + 0.0001f), lightness, alpha);
911    }
912
913    /**
914     * Gets a color as a HSLuv packed float given floats representing HSL hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
915     * You should usually prefer just using {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)} to get colors with these values.
916     * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
917     * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
918     * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
919     * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
920     * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
921     * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
922     * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
923     *
924     * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
925     * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
926     * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
927     * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
928     * @return a HSLuv float encoding a color with the given properties
929     */
930    public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
931        if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
932            return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000));
933        } else if (lightness >= 0.999f) {
934            return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x00FF0000);
935        } else {
936            return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
937        }
938    }
939
940    /**
941     * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
942     * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details.
943     *
944     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
945     * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
946     */
947    public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
948        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
949        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
950        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
951        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
952
953        // HSLuv to Lch
954        float C;
955        if (L > 0.99999f) {
956            L = 1;
957            C = 0;
958        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
959            L = 0;
960            C = 0;
961        } else
962            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
963
964        // Lch to Luv
965        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
966        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
967
968        // Luv to XYZ
969        float x, y, z;
970        if (L < 0.00001f) {
971            x = 0;
972            y = 0;
973            z = 0;
974        } else {
975            if (L <= 0.08f)
976                y = L / kappa;
977            else {
978                y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
979                y *= y * y;
980            }
981            float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
982            float varU = U * iL + refU;
983            float varV = V * iL + refV;
984            x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
985            z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
986        }
987        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
988        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
989        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
990        float X, Y, W;
991        if(g < b) {
992            X = b;
993            Y = g;
994        }
995        else {
996            X = g;
997            Y = b;
998        }
999        if(r < X) {
1000            W = r;
1001        }
1002        else {
1003            W = X;
1004            X = r;
1005        }
1006        return X - Math.min(W, Y);
1007    }
1008
1009    /**
1010     * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for HSLuv. This
1011     * ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f (white).
1012     *
1013     * @param encoded a packed float HSLuv color
1014     * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
1015     */
1016    public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
1017        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1018        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1019        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
1020        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1021
1022        // HSLuv to Lch
1023        float C;
1024        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1025            L = 1;
1026            C = 0;
1027        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
1028            L = 0;
1029            C = 0;
1030        } else
1031            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
1032
1033        // Lch to Luv
1034        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
1035        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
1036
1037        // Luv to XYZ
1038        float x, y, z;
1039        if (L < 0.00001f) {
1040            x = 0;
1041            y = 0;
1042            z = 0;
1043        } else {
1044            if (L <= 0.08f)
1045                y = L / kappa;
1046            else {
1047                y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
1048                y *= y * y;
1049            }
1050            float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
1051            float varU = U * iL + refU;
1052            float varV = V * iL + refV;
1053            x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
1054            z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
1055        }
1056        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
1057        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
1058        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
1059        float X, Y, W;
1060        if(g < b) {
1061            X = b;
1062            Y = g;
1063        }
1064        else {
1065            X = g;
1066            Y = b;
1067        }
1068        if(r < X) {
1069            W = r;
1070        }
1071        else {
1072            W = X;
1073            X = r;
1074        }
1075        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
1076        return X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
1077    }
1078
1079    /**
1080     * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
1081     * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
1082     *
1083     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1084     * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
1085     * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
1086     */
1087    public static float hue(final float encoded) {
1088        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1089        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1090        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
1091        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1092
1093        // HSLuv to Lch
1094        float C;
1095        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1096            L = 1;
1097            C = 0;
1098        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
1099            L = 0;
1100            C = 0;
1101        } else
1102            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
1103
1104        // Lch to Luv
1105        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
1106        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
1107
1108        // Luv to XYZ
1109        float x, y, z;
1110        if (L < 0.00001f) {
1111            x = 0;
1112            y = 0;
1113            z = 0;
1114        } else {
1115            if (L <= 0.08f)
1116                y = L / kappa;
1117            else {
1118                y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
1119                y *= y * y;
1120            }
1121            float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
1122            float varU = U * iL + refU;
1123            float varV = V * iL + refV;
1124            x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
1125            z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
1126        }
1127        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
1128        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
1129        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
1130        float X, Y, Z, W;
1131        if(g < b) {
1132            X = b;
1133            Y = g;
1134            Z = -1f;
1135            W = 2f / 3f;
1136        }
1137        else {
1138            X = g;
1139            Y = b;
1140            Z = 0f;
1141            W = -1f / 3f;
1142        }
1143        if(r < X) {
1144            Z = W;
1145            W = r;
1146        }
1147        else {
1148            W = X;
1149            X = r;
1150        }
1151        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
1152        return Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
1153    }
1154    /**
1155     * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
1156     * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not HSLuv! Takes
1157     * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
1158     * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is likely to be
1159     * different from the result of {@code basis} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
1160     * This won't allocate any objects.
1161     * <br>
1162     * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
1163     * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
1164     * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
1165     * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
1166     * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
1167     *
1168     * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
1169     * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
1170     * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
1171     * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
1172     * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
1173     * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
1174     */
1175    public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
1176        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
1177        final float li = Math.min(Math.max(light + reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f), 0f), 1f);
1178        opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 25) / 127f, 0f), 1f);
1179        if (li <= 0.001f)
1180            return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000));
1181        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1182        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
1183        float L = li;
1184//        float L = (1f/1.16f)*(li + 0.16f);
1185
1186        // HSLuv to Lch
1187        float C;
1188        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1189            L = 1;
1190            C = 0;
1191        } else
1192            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
1193
1194        // Lch to Luv
1195        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
1196        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
1197
1198        // Luv to XYZ
1199        float x, y, z;
1200        if (L <= 0.08f)
1201            y = L / kappa;
1202        else {
1203            y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
1204            y *= y * y;
1205        }
1206        float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
1207        float varU = U * iL + refU;
1208        float varV = V * iL + refV;
1209        x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
1210        z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
1211        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
1212        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
1213        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
1214        float X, Y, Z, W;
1215        if(g < b) {
1216            X = b;
1217            Y = g;
1218            Z = -1f;
1219            W = 2f / 3f;
1220        }
1221        else {
1222            X = g;
1223            Y = b;
1224            Z = 0f;
1225            W = -1f / 3f;
1226        }
1227        if(r < X) {
1228            Z = W;
1229            W = r;
1230        }
1231        else {
1232            W = X;
1233            X = r;
1234        }
1235        final float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
1236        final float lum = X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
1237        hue += Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
1238        saturation += (X - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
1239        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
1240    }
1241
1242
1243    /**
1244     * Given a packed float HSLuv color, this edits its H, S, L, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
1245     * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1246     * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. H is wrapped, while S,
1247     * L, and alpha are clamped.
1248     * @param encoded a packed float HSLuv color
1249     * @param addH how much to add to the H channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1250     * @param addS how much to add to the S channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1251     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1252     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1253     * @return a packed float HSLuv color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1254     */
1255    public static float editHSLuv(float encoded, float addH, float addS, float addL, float addAlpha) {
1256        return editHSLuv(encoded, addH, addS, addL, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
1257    }
1258    /**
1259     * Given a packed float HSLuv color, this edits its H, S, L, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel
1260     * by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping (this
1261     * wraps H instead of clamping it). This means the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has
1262     * {@code addL} added, and then is clamped to the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value
1263     * (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want
1264     * to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. You can multiply S by 0 to make
1265     * a grayscale color, or by a large value to make any non-grayscale color more vibrant. Multiplying H generally
1266     * isn't very useful, but adding to H can be used to do hue cycling (because H wraps).
1267     * @param encoded a packed float HSLuv color
1268     * @param addH how much to add to the H channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1269     * @param addS how much to add to the S channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1270     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1271     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1272     * @param mulH how much to multiply the H channel by; should be non-negative (not always)
1273     * @param mulS how much to multiply the S channel by; usually non-negative
1274     * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1275     * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
1276     * @return a packed float HSLuv color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1277     */
1278    public static float editHSLuv(float encoded, float addH, float addS, float addL, float addAlpha,
1279                                  float mulH, float mulS, float mulL, float mulAlpha) {
1280        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1281        float H = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1282        float S = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
1283        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1284        float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1285
1286        H = H * mulH + addH;
1287        H -= floor(H);
1288        S = Math.min(Math.max(S * mulS + addS, 0f), 1f);
1289        L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
1290        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
1291        return hsluv(H, S, L, alpha);
1292    }
1293
1294    /**
1295     * The "H" channel of the given packed float in HSLuv format, which is its hue; ranges from 0.0f to 1.0f .
1296     * You can edit the H of a color with {@link #rotateH(float, float)}.
1297     *
1298     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1299     * @return the H value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
1300     */
1301    public static float channelH(final float encoded)
1302    {
1303        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
1304    }
1305
1306    /**
1307     * The "S" channel of the given packed float in HSLuv format, which is its saturation; ranges from 0.0f to
1308     * 1.0f . You can edit the S of a color with {@link #enrich(float, float)} and {@link #dullen(float, float)}.
1309     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1310     * @return the S value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
1311     */
1312    public static float channelS(final float encoded)
1313    {
1314        return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
1315    }
1316
1317    /**
1318     * The "L" channel of the given packed float in HSLuv format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
1319     * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
1320     *
1321     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1322     * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
1323     */
1324    public static float channelL(final float encoded)
1325    {
1326        return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
1327    }
1328
1329    /**
1330     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
1331     * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
1332     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1333     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1334     * towards white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha, hue, and
1335     * saturation of start as-is.
1336     * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
1337     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1338     * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
1339     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
1340     */
1341    public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
1342        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1343        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
1344    }
1345
1346    /**
1347     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
1348     * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
1349     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1350     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1351     * towards black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha, hue, and
1352     * saturation of start as-is.
1353     * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
1354     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1355     * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
1356     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
1357     */
1358    public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
1359        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1360        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
1361    }
1362
1363    /**
1364     * Moves the color of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating the color). While change
1365     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
1366     * from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only S, and won't change hue, lightness, or alpha.
1367     * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
1368     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1369     * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
1370     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
1371     */
1372    public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
1373        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1374        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
1375    }
1376
1377    /**
1378     * Brings the color of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating the color). While
1379     * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
1380     * from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only S, and won't change hue, lightness, or alpha.
1381     * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
1382     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1383     * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
1384     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
1385     */
1386    public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
1387        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1388        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
1389    }
1390
1391    /**
1392     * Cycles the hue of the packed float color by change. If change is 0f, this returns start as-is. If change is
1393     * positive, this rotates from red to orange to yellow to green, and so on. If change is negative, this instead
1394     * rotates from green to yellow to orange to red.  A change value is typically between -1f and 1f; if change is
1395     * exactly an integer, then this will wrap around in a perfect circle and produce no change. The start value should
1396     * be a packed color, as from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations
1397     * of temporary Colors. This only changes H, and won't change saturation, lightness, or alpha.
1398     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1399     * @param change how much to rotate hue by, as a float typically between -1 and 1; further from 0 rotates more
1400     * @return a packed float that represents a color like start but with a rotated hue
1401     */
1402    public static float rotateH(final float start, final float change) {
1403        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
1404        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (256f * change)) & 0xFF) | other);
1405    }
1406
1407    /**
1408     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
1409     * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1410     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1411     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1412     * towards transparent. This won't change the H, S, or L of the color.
1413     * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
1414     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1415     * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
1416     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
1417     */
1418    public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
1419        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1420        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1421    }
1422
1423    /**
1424     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
1425     * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1426     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
1427     * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
1428     * lerp towards transparent. This won't change the H, S, or L of the color.
1429     * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
1430     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1431     * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
1432     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
1433     */
1434    public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
1435        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1436        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1437    }
1438
1439    /**
1440     * Given a packed float HSLuv color {@code mainColor} and another HSLuv color that it should be made to contrast
1441     * with, gets a packed float HSLuv color with roughly inverted lightness but the same hue, saturation, and alpha.
1442     * This won't ever produce black or other very dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for
1443     * lightness values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a
1444     * foreground when displayed on a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the
1445     * lightness unchanged if the hues of the contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different.
1446     * This has nothing to do with the contrast channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can
1447     * make too-similar lightness values further apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor}
1448     * to maximize its lightness difference from {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
1449     * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
1450     * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
1451     * @return a different HSLuv packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
1452     */
1453    public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1454    {
1455        final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
1456                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
1457                H = (bits & 0xff),
1458//                S = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1459                L = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
1460                cH = (contrastBits & 0xff),
1461//                cS = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1462                cL = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
1463        if(Math.abs(H - cH) >= 90)
1464            return mainColor;
1465        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFE00FFFF) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 128 : 128 - L * 0.45f) << 16);
1466    }
1467
1468    /**
1469     * Given a packed float HSLuv color {@code mainColor} and another HSLuv color that it should be made to contrast
1470     * with, gets a packed float HSLuv color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
1471     * but the same hue, saturation, and opacity. This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well
1472     * as a foreground when displayed on a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
1473     * <br>
1474     * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
1475     * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant hues. Because it
1476     * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
1477     * @param mainColor a packed HSLuv float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
1478     * @param contrastingColor a packed HSLuv float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the L of this
1479     * @return a different packed HSLuv float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
1480     */
1481    public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1482    {
1483        final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
1484        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFE00FFFF) | ((contrast >>> 16) + 128 & 0xFF) + (main >>> 16 & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1485    }
1486
1487    /**
1488     * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
1489     * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
1490     * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
1491     * <br>
1492     * Calling {@code offsetLightness(mainColor)} is the same as calling
1493     * {@code ColorTools.differentiateLightness(mainColor, mainColor)}.
1494     * @param mainColor a packed HSLuv float color
1495     * @return a different packed HSLuv float color, with its L channel changed.
1496     */
1497    public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
1498        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
1499        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE00FFFF) | ((decoded >>> 16) + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1500    }
1501
1502    /**
1503     * Makes the additive HSLuv color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
1504     * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
1505     * returns {@code Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
1506     * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery. This only
1507     * affects the saturation and lightness of the color; its hue and alpha are unchanged.
1508     * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
1509     * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
1510     * @return a HSLuv float color between gray and {@code color}
1511     */
1512    public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
1513        final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
1514                sS = 0x80, sL = 0x80,
1515                eH = (e & 0xFF), eS = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eL = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1516        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(eH
1517                | (((int) (sS + fraction * (eS - sS)) & 0xFF) << 8)
1518                | (((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF) << 16)
1519                | (eAlpha << 24));
1520    }
1521
1522    /**
1523     * Returns true always; HSLuv colors are always in-gamut.
1524     * @param packed a packed float color as HSLuv
1525     * @return true
1526     */
1527    public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1528    {
1529        return true;
1530    }
1531
1532    /**
1533     * Returns true if S and L are each between 0 and 1; if valid, HSLuv colors are always in-gamut.
1534     * @param H hue, as an unbounded float
1535     * @param S saturation, as a float from 0 to 1
1536     * @param L lightness, as a float from 0 to 1
1537     * @return true if S and L are both between 0 and 1
1538     */
1539    public static boolean inGamut(float H, float S, float L)
1540    {
1541        return (S >= 0f && S <= 1.0f && L >= 0f && L <= 1.0f);
1542    }
1543
1544    /**
1545     * Returns its argument unchanged; HSLuv colors are always in-gamut.
1546     * @param packed a packed float color in HSLuv format
1547     * @return {@code packed}, unchanged
1548     */
1549    public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1550        return packed;
1551    }
1552
1553    /**
1554     * Identical to calling {@link #clamp(float, float, float, float)} with 1f as its last parameter.
1555     * @param H hue; will be wrapped between 0 and 1
1556     * @param S saturation; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1557     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1558     * @return an HSLuv color with the specified channel values, wrapped or clamped as appropriate
1559     */
1560    public static float limitToGamut(float H, float S, float L) {
1561        return clamp(H - floor(H), S, L, 1f);
1562    }
1563    /**
1564     * Identical to calling {@link #clamp(float, float, float, float)} with 1f as its last parameter.
1565     * @param H hue; will be wrapped between 0 and 1
1566     * @param S saturation; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1567     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1568     * @param alpha opacity; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1569     * @return an HSLuv color with the specified channel values, wrapped or clamped as appropriate
1570     */
1571    public static float limitToGamut(float H, float S, float L, float alpha) {
1572        return clamp(H, S, L, alpha);
1573    }
1574
1575    /**
1576     * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
1577     * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
1578     * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
1579     * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
1580     * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the H, S, and L of the
1581     * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
1582     * isn't greater than the variance.
1583     * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1584     * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
1585     * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
1586     * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
1587     */
1588    public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
1589        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
1590        float H = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1591        float S = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
1592        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1593        final float limit = variance * variance;
1594        float dist, x, y, z;
1595        for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
1596            x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1597            y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1598            z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1599            seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1600            dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
1601            if(dist <= limit)
1602                return clamp(H + x, S + y, L + z, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
1603        }
1604        return color;
1605    }
1606
1607    /**
1608     * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut and should be uniformly distributed.
1609     * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
1610     * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1611     */
1612    public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1613        return hsluv(random.nextFloat(), random.nextFloat(), random.nextFloat(), 1f);
1614    }
1615
1616    /**
1617     * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1618     * This is only present for legacy compatibility; new code should use {@link #randomColor(Random)}.
1619     * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
1620     * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1621     * @deprecated Use {@link #randomColor(Random)} instead.
1622     */
1623    @Deprecated
1624    public static float randomizedColor(Random random) {
1625        return hsluv(random.nextFloat(), random.nextFloat(), random.nextFloat(), 1f);
1626    }
1627    /**
1628     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
1629     * as from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use
1630     * end). Both start and end must use HSLuv. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
1631     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1632     * @param end the target color as a packed float
1633     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
1634     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
1635     */
1636    public static float lerpFloatColors(final float start, final float end, float change) {
1637        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(end),
1638                hs = (s & 0xFF), ss = (s >>> 8) & 0xFF, ls = (s >>> 16) & 0xFF, as = s >>> 24 & 0xFE,
1639                he = (e & 0xFF), se = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, le = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1640        float Hs = hs / 255f, Cs, Ls;
1641        if (ls == 255) {
1642            Ls = 1f;
1643            Cs = 0f;
1644        } else if (ls == 0) {
1645            Ls = 0f;
1646            Cs = 0f;
1647        } else {
1648            Ls = ls / 255f;
1649            Cs = chromaLimit(Hs, Ls) * (ss / 255f);
1650        }
1651        // Lch to Luv
1652        float Us = TrigTools.cosTurns(Hs) * Cs;
1653        float Vs = TrigTools.sinTurns(Hs) * Cs;
1654
1655        float He = he / 255f, Ce, Le;
1656        if (le == 255) {
1657            Le = 1f;
1658            Ce = 0f;
1659        } else if (le == 0) {
1660            Le = 0f;
1661            Ce = 0f;
1662        } else {
1663            Le = le / 255f;
1664            Ce = chromaLimit(He, Le) * (se / 255f);
1665        }
1666        // Lch to Luv
1667        float Ue = TrigTools.cosTurns(He) * Ce;
1668        float Ve = TrigTools.sinTurns(He) * Ce;
1669
1670        float H, S, L, U, V;
1671
1672        L = (Ls + change * (Le - Ls));
1673        U = (Us + change * (Ue - Us));
1674        V = (Vs + change * (Ve - Vs));
1675
1676        // Luv to Lch
1677        H = TrigTools.atan2Turns(V, U);
1678
1679
1680        // Lch to HSLuv
1681        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1682            return Palette.WHITE;
1683        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
1684            return Palette.BLACK;
1685        } else {
1686            S = Math.min((float)Math.sqrt(U * U + V * V) / chromaLimit(H, L), 1);
1687        }
1688        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1689                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(H * 255.999f), 0), 255)
1690                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(S * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8
1691                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(L * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16
1692                        | (((int) (as + change * (ae - as)) & 0xFE) << 24));
1693    }
1694
1695    /**
1696     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change, but keeps the alpha of start and uses the
1697     * alpha of end as an extra factor that can affect how much to change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
1698     * as from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use
1699     * end). Both start and end must use HSLuv. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
1700     * @param start the starting color as a packed float; alpha will be preserved
1701     * @param end the target color as a packed float; alpha will not be used directly, and will instead be multiplied with change
1702     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
1703     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
1704     */
1705    public static float lerpFloatColorsBlended(final float start, final float end, float change) {
1706        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(end),
1707                as = s & 0xFE000000;
1708        change *= (e >>> 25) / 127f;
1709        return lerpFloatColors(start, BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(as | (e & 0xFFFFFF)), change);
1710    }
1711
1712    /**
1713     * Returns a 1:1 mix of color0 and color1. All colors should use the same color space.
1714     * This is the same as calling {@link #lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} with a change of 0.5.
1715     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
1716     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
1717     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1718     */
1719    public static float mix(float color0, float color1) {
1720        return lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f);
1721    }
1722
1723    /**
1724     * Returns a 1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, and color2. All colors should use the same color space.
1725     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
1726     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
1727     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
1728     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1729     */
1730    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2) {
1731        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f);
1732    }
1733
1734    /**
1735     * Returns a 1:1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, color2, and color3. All colors should use the same color space.
1736     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
1737     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
1738     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
1739     * @param color3 the fourth color to mix, as a packed float color
1740     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1741     */
1742    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2, float color3) {
1743        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f), color3, 0.25f);
1744    }
1745
1746    /**
1747     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
1748     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
1749     * @param colors an array or varargs of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
1750     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1751     */
1752    public static float mix(float... colors) {
1753        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0)
1754            return 0f; // transparent, usually
1755        float result = colors[0];
1756        for (int i = 1; i < colors.length; i++) {
1757            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / (i + 1f));
1758        }
1759        return result;
1760    }
1761
1762    /**
1763     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
1764     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
1765     * This is mostly useful in conjunction with {@link com.github.tommyettinger.ds.FloatList}, using its {@code items}
1766     * for colors, typically 0 for offset, and its {@code size} for size.
1767     * @param colors an array of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
1768     * @param offset the index of the first item in {@code colors} to use
1769     * @param size how many items from {@code colors} to use
1770     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1771     */
1772    public static float mix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
1773        final int end = offset + size;
1774        if(colors == null || colors.length < end || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
1775            return 0f; // transparent, usually
1776        float result = colors[offset];
1777        for (int i = offset + 1, denom = 2; i < end; i++, denom++) {
1778            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / denom);
1779        }
1780        return result;
1781    }
1782
1783    /**
1784     * Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array ofr varargs of alternating floats
1785     * representing colors and weights, as with {@code color, weight, color, weight...}.
1786     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
1787     * @param colors an array or varargs that should contain alternating {@code color, weight, color, weight...} floats
1788     * @return a mix of all colors given respecting their weights, as a packed float color
1789     */
1790    public static float unevenMix(float... colors) {
1791        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0) return 0f;
1792        if(colors.length <= 2) return colors[0];
1793        return unevenMix(colors, 0, colors.length);
1794    }
1795
1796    /**
1797     * Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array of alternating floats representing
1798     * colors and weights, as with {@code color, weight, color, weight...}, starting at {@code offset} in the array and
1799     * continuing for {@code size} indices in the array. The {@code size} should be an even number 2 or greater,
1800     * otherwise it will be reduced by 1. The weights can be any non-negative finite float values; this method handles
1801     * normalizing them internally.
1802     * @param colors starting at {@code offset}, this should contain alternating {@code color, weight, color, weight...} floats
1803     * @param offset where to start reading from in {@code colors}
1804     * @param size how many indices to read from {@code colors}; must be an even number
1805     * @return the mixed color, as a packed float in the same color space as the given float colors
1806     */
1807    public static float unevenMix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
1808        size &= -2;
1809        final int end = offset + size;
1810        if(colors == null || colors.length < end || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
1811            return 0f; // transparent, usually
1812        float result = colors[offset];
1813        float current = colors[offset + 1], total = current;
1814        for (int i = offset+3; i < end; i += 2) {
1815            total += colors[i];
1816        }
1817        total = 1f / total;
1818        current *= total;
1819        for (int i = offset+3; i < end; i += 2) {
1820            float mixColor = colors[i-1], weight = colors[i] * total;
1821            result = lerpFloatColors(result, mixColor, weight / (current += weight));
1822        }
1823        return result;
1824    }
1825}
